direction.raw_text: The front room is cluttered with his childhood. Most noticeable are the pianos: two tiny uprights, perfectly matched, their simulated ivory keys yellowed with age.  Above them, pressed between glass and framed, are the music ribbons, faded by twenty years of sunlight. Finally, there is the sheet music, dusty and dog-eared, piled everywhere in drunken stacks. This and all else in the room Jack confronts slowly, warily, but with a noticeable dispassion, until his eyes fall upon a photograph. In it, he and Frank are standing alonside a tall man in baggy slacks, safe within the arc of his long arms. Frank is staring straight into the camera, neat, clean, perfectly posed, but Jack, a year younger, his shirt too big, is caught in profile, looking up at the tall man with an almost worshipful gaze.

direction.raw_text: Oh, look how you're growing. My little boys ... Jack's eyes drift from the photograph to his mother and brother, sitting close together in the love seat, laughing.  After a moment, their voices fade and Jack looks back to the children on the screen, like two tiny men, mirror images of one another. At first the changes are subtle. Little Jack's tie is askew, his shirt missing a button. But as the years flick by, the brothers resemble one another less and less, until finally, the little boy that was Jack is completely gone and in his place is a slouching, tousle-haired adolescent in rumpled coat and open collar, a cigarette hanging disdainfully from his lip. A woman's hand darts into the frame and plucks the offending cigarette away in a flash.

Right after they finish up here, they're going to be manning the phones.  Maybe we can even convince them to raffle off a few piano lessons if we're lucky.  What do you think? The audience applauds.  Jack glares at Frank.  He shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, all right then.  What are we waiting for?  Take it away, guys. Jack and Frank poise their hands over their pianos and begin to play.  As the music rises, the studio becomes very quiet, almost still.  Unfortunately, Jack and Frank are barely through the opening passage when a thunderously
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: begins to RING.  Suddenly, Vince steps out again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh oh.  We know what that means, don't we?  It's time to turn the board over. (to Jack, Frank) I'm afraid you fellas'll just have to wait a minute. Let's bring out the board. Two post-pubescent giants roll out the tote board right in front of Jack and Frank. Jack looks positively homicidal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack ... Jack kicks out the piano bench and starts to leave. Then, seeing the kid in the wheelchair, he grabs the basketball and fires it at Vince.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the -- JACK (pointing) You're a fucking creep, you know that.  I oughta kick your ass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack, you're on television.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shut up, Frank. Earl of the sweatshirt and cap puts his hand on Jack's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you say we go for a walk, pal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get your hand off me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, friend.  I can smell it on you. Get yourself a cup of coffee.  You'll forget what you're angry about.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go fuck yourself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a real tough guy when the ladies are around, aren't you, Ace?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't see any ladies here. Except maybe you. That does it.  Earl takes hold of Jack's collar and starts to-wrestle him roughly toward the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, leave him alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do your brother a favor and have his mouth sewn up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a lousy dancer, Earl.  Don't you know the man's supposed to lead? Earl shoves Jack into the hallway, hard. Jack stumbles back against the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who do you think you are, asshole? Liberace?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack walks down the street, mindless of the rain. Frank follows a few yards behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack.  We just,passed the car. Jack.  This is a tuxedo.  Three hundred dollars. (pause) You gonna talk to me?  Or is this Jack's famous silent act?  Look, it was for publicity. Do you understand?  Publicity. Jack stops and stares at Frank incredulously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What-are you?  A fucking moron? It's three o'clock in the morning, Frank.  Who's watching?  Your wife? Maybe you can get us a gig playing Little Frank's birthday party. What do you think?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look.  I didn't know when we were going to be on until yesterday.  What was I supposed to do? I had the pianos anyway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Basketballs, Frank.  You had us playing for basketballs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry.  I should've checked it out.  I screwed up.  But that doesn't mean you walk out in the middle of a gig.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It wasn't professional, Jack.  It was a stunt. A stupid-ass stunt. Jack just stares at Frank, as if looking at a stranger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's happening to you, Frank?  You been kissing ass so long you're starting to like it?  You let that guy turn us into clowns tonight.  We were always small time, but we were never clowns, Frank. What's happened to your dignity?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dignity?  Who the hell are you to talk about dignity? Frank suddenly steps forward and reaches into Jack's jacket, coming away with a bottle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This where you get your dignity, Jack? This is where you get your courage? Jack tries to grab the bottle but Frank holds it away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, let's do it straight for once, shall we? Frank tosses the BOTTLE into the street, where it
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me explain something to you, little brother. See, I've got people who depend on me.  I've got a wife and two children who expect to wake up every morning with food on the table and heat in the house. I got a mortgage.  I got car payments.  I got Ma's medical bills. Oh yeah, and I got you.  Yeah, you. Jack the shadow who's so cool and so hip and so fucking sure he's better than everyone else.  Don't you think I'd like to walk up to one of these assholes and blow smoke in his face?  Goddamn right I would. But I can't.  Because I have to be responsible, little brother.  I have to make sure the numbers balance out in my favor at the end of each month so everyone can go on living their lives.  You don't win medals for it, but you can be damn sure you'd all take notice if I folded up shop.  So don't talk to me about dignity, little brother.  You're drawing on a weak hand. Jack stares at Frank through the rain, then turns and begins to walk away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Great.  Terrific.  Walk away.  You're good at that, Jack.  Just don't forget to stop off for another bottle of courage on your way home. (pause) That's what he'd do. Jack stops, his back to Frank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've found the perfect solution to all the pain in the world, haven't you, little brother? Eight-fifty a bottle, available any time day or night at your friendly neighborhood liquor store. You're weak, Jack.  Just like he was. Jack turns, tough and dangerous in the darkness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stay off it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, let's stay on it.  I'm sick and tired of watching you make him up into some kinda god. For Christ sake, Jack, he died doing a stupid bullshit jig.  He left a wife and two sons.  He wasn't a hero.  He was a fool.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You weren't there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right.  I wasn't there.  I don't have the luxury of being a witness to tragedy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fuck you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, fuck you.  And fuck him too. Fuck the both-of you. Jack suddenly bolts for,ward and grabs Frank by the lapels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, what're you doing?  Hey! Jack flings Frank against the wall, pounding, pulling and slamming him in a fitful rage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack! ... Jack! ... Frank slides to the ground, afraid, trying to protect himself.  Jack hovers over him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's it feel to have your little brother beat the shit out of you?  Huh?  Huh! Jack comes down with a vicious fist at Frank's face. Frank holds up his hands, trying to shield himself, and catches a blow on his fingers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My hands!  My hands! Jack grabs one of Frank's hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your hands.  Your hands couldn't take the blue ribbon on amateur night. Jack bends back Frank's fingers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's weak now, big brother? Jack pushes Frank's fingers until the knuckles crack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack!  JACK! Frank's voice echoes high above the sound of the rain. Suddenly Jack stops.  Looking at Frank's hand, still clasped in his, he seems as shocked by his own behavior as Frank.  Letting go, he steps back awkwardly and looks at his brother, beaten, to the ground, his tuxedo ripped and dirty.  He stares at his own hands, the knuckles split and bleeding.  He no longer looks dangerous.  He looks hollow, frightened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm through with it.  I can't do it anymore. Frank, rubbing his fingers, glances up at Jack, but Jack just turns away, leaving Frank on the sidewalk, and disappears into the rain.  MUSIC begins.  A sad, plaintive solo piano.  And we see:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack, crossing the street to his apartment, the rain over now. Frank, driving home, his face swollen and bruised in the dim glow of the streetlights. Jack, letting himself into his apartment and standing there.  Alone. Frank, easing the car into the driveway, turning off the engine. Jack, taking a bottle from the kitchen, moving numbly. Frank, much later, still sitting in the driveway as the sun begins to come up. Jack, sitting in the phone booth, the bottle in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The next morning.  Jack is sitting on the windowsill, watching the RAIN DRUM the GLASS.  He glances at the phone across the room, takes another look at the rain, then goes to the phone.  He picks it up hesitantly, then dials. It rings.  Again.  Again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello? Jack blinks.  It's Cindy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello ... Hellooooo ... (fainter) Daddy.  Daddy!  Someone's on the phone and they won't talk. Jack sets the phone back down on the cradle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack stands in a dark bar.  It is early morning and the light from the street gives the room a ghostly atmosphere. A big, beefy MAN with a bar towel hooked in his belt is talking to Jack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If they wanna talk about their wife, you listen. If they wanna talk about their job, you listen. If they wanna talk about their parakeet, you listen. That's it, six nights a week, nine to one or until I send you home.  Okay? Jack nods and points to the piano in the corner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How many you need? Jack walks over to the giano and strikes a note.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's out of tune.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Trust me, the way I fix a martini, it'll be in tune. The MUSIC RETURNS, sad and plaintive, and we see:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank, attempting to give piano lessons to a brother and sister tandem who would be better served by an obedience school.  While the little girl pounds incessantly on the piano, her brother runs circles around the room, destroying everything in sight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and we see:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack and Eddie, going for a walk, passing the diner where Jack and Frank's pictures are still displayed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and we see:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack, in the bar, playing the music we've been hearing throughout the previous scenes.  It is after midnight and the tables are empty.  Only a few somber men remain at the bar.  They do not appear to be music lovers. As Jack finishes, he takes a cloth and wipes the keys. There is a glass on the piano with money in it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought the Bakers didn't take tips. Jack glances up, but he knows the voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I give it all to charity. Susie nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Saw the sign outside.  Got your own sign, huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.  Got my own sign.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We outgrew each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, well, like I said, it didn't figure.  You two.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't pick your brother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So how's the cat food business?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terrific.  I'm doing vegetables next week. Jack nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What kind?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vegetables.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. Carrots.  And peas.  None of the important ones. Susie tries a smile.  Takes a breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen... you want to get a drink?  I got a new place.  Or we could go to a bar ... (looking around) Well, maybe not a bar.  But I know a place uptown, if you want -- JACK I've given it up. Susie stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No kidding?  Well ... I guess you can't do a reunion over tomato juice, can you? (pause) Anyway, if you're ever in the neighborhood ... I wrote it down. Susie takes a slip of paper from her purse and hands it to Jack.  They lock eyes for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell egghead I said hi.  If you see him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I see him. Susie nods and walks toward the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey. (as she stops) You got pretty eyes. Susie smiles.  As she leaves, Jack studies the slip of paper in his hand, then drops it in the tip glass. He glances at the door, swinging slowly shut in Susie's wake, then reaches into his coat and takes out a bottle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank sits alone in the darkness of the den.  The cardboard stand-up is there, along with several old photographs, including one showing two skinny kids in tuxes standing with a glamorous Peggy Lee.  After a moment, Donna enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank?  It's late, honey. Frank stays staring at the photograph of Peggy Lee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Lerner called after dinner.  Robbie can't make his lesson tomorrow. Donna waits for her husband to say something, then sees the photograph in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know how good he is?  It's like breathing with him.  I've always envied it.  But tonight, looking at all this -- at his face -- I don't know. Maybe it's worse.  For him. (gesturing to the piano) It's funny.  When I sit here and play ... nothing. But when I was up there with him... It was like I had the gift, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank is standing in the hallway of his house, leaning against the bathroom door.  It's locked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Jeremy.  Open the door. Somewhere in the house, the PHONE RINGS. Frank ignores it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeremy.  You want me to call your father? He's not going to be very happy when he hears he's spending fifteen dollars an hour for you to sit on the toilet. Donna, looking shaken, steps into the hallway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honey ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You believe this?  The kid won't come out.  I'm playing 'Camptown Races' for him and the next thing I know he's locked himself in the bathroom. There's nothing sharp in there, is there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honey ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are our kids? Has he got one of them in there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank. Frank finally looks at his wife.  She's crying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack rushes down a hospital corridor and heads for the nurses station.  As he moves to the counter, Donna appears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Donna.  Where is she? Donna just shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We tried the apartment, but after that we didn't know where to call. Jack looks frozen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank'll be back in a moment. He took Little Frank to the bathroom. Jack begins to back away slowly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack moves aimlessly down the street, slipping in and out of shadows.  Finally he stops inside a closed storefront, his back up against the window, and looks down at his hands.  They're shaking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack stands in an apartment hallway, waiting. After a moment, the door opens.  It's Susie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, this is some surprise. (seeing his face) Hey ... You don't look so good, pal. Susie studies Jack as he glances around the hallway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack? Jack looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want to come in? He nods.  Susie steps back and Jack enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me get the light.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. He stares directly into her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leave it dark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack is standing at the foot of the bed, looking down at Susie's naked back as she sleeps.  He studies her face as if looking for something, then takes his coat and begins to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I used to do that. Jack turns.  Susie is looking at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sneak out in the morning.  Before the guy could wake up and ruin it.  Never figured I'd be on the other end of it, though.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't want to wake you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks.  For letting me in last night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Funny how life repeats itself, huh?  Over and over. Like a song. Jack looks at Susie for a long moment, then nods and turns for the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey. Jack stops, his hand on the doorknob.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Am I gonna see you again? Jack looks at her face, beautiful in the morning light.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.  You're gonna see me again. Susie smiles slightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack is standing across the street from his mother's house, just looking.  After a moment, he crosses the street.  As he moves up the drive, he takes notice of the tree growing in the front yard and crosses to it, kneeling by the trunk and studying the scars there -- cat's claws -- running vertically up the tree, the damage smoothed and widened by time.  He runs his fingers over the imperfection, then stands and walks toward the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Through the screen door, Jack can hear a CLICKING sound and see partially into the front door.  Half the room is cast in shadow, the other in blinding light. He opens the door and enters.
direction.name: direction
